Air pollution is one of the urban environmental problems needing urgent solutions. In addition, it is an important topic in atmospheric environment studies, greatly affecting the construc- tion of ecological civilization in China (Chen et al., 2020). Resources have been largely consumed and the environment damaged by the rapid development of industrialization and urbanization. This has led to severe atmospheric problems such as smog and pho- tochemical pollution (Wang et al., 2018, 2021). In addition, northern China is vulnerable to the impact of sandstorms, which not only brings serious air pol- lution, but also poses great harm to surface conditions and human health (Yu et al., 2019). Severe air pol- lution had a serious impact on people‚Äôs production, life, and health that have been observed. Incidences of respiratory diseases, for example, also significantly increased in winter (Buoli et al., 2018; Leiva et al., 2013; Wang & Hao, 2012). Humanity is becoming increasingly concerned about the environment while improving the quality of life. Thus, air quality has gradually attracted increasing attention (Li, 2018). Consequently, the Ministry of Environmental Pro- tection of the People‚Äôs Republic of China issued the ambient air quality standard on February 29, 2012. The air quality status is presented using the unified evaluation standard. The air quality index (AQI), a comprehensive indi- cator to measure air pollution (Bai et al., 2018), is often used to quantitatively analyze regional air qual- ity. The air quality index is a new national air quality evaluation standard released in February 2012. The higher the value, the more serious the air pollution condition. There are six major pollutants involved in air quality evaluation, including PM2.5, PM10, SO2, NO2, O3, and CO. By calculating the air quality sub- index of these six pollutants, the maximum value is taken as the value of AQI. Currently, studies based on the air quality index mainly include ‚ë† the spatial and temporal distribution of air pollution, which studies the regional differences in air quality from different spatial scales (e.g., cities (Li, 2016), urban agglomer- ations (Liu & Xin, 2019), provinces (Cao et al., 2020), and countries (Zhang et al., 2020a, 2020b, 2020c)) and the time series characteristics of air quality from tions) (Dong et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2020); ‚ë° sources and influencing factors of air pollution (e.g., air qual- ity is affected by natural (Di & Li, 2019), socioeco- nomic (Xu et al., 2019), and comprehensive factors) (Han et al., 2019; Sun et al., 2019; Xu et al., 2017); ‚ë¢ prediction of future air quality changes through different individual or mixed models (Wang, 2018; Zhao, 2016; Zhu et al., 2020); and ‚ë£ study on the correlation between air pollution and the incidence of certain diseases (He, 2018, 2019). In addition, air quality differences have been analyzed based on dif- ferent spatial scales and different series of spatial and temporal scales. The temporal and spatial AQI varia- tion characteristics are mainly studied through cluster analysis (Shen et al., 2017; Zhao et al., 2016), spatial interpolation (Zhao, 2016), spatial autocorrelation (Lin & Wang, 2016; Liu et al., 2018; Yao et al., 2021; Zhang et al., 2020a, 2020b, 2020c), hot spot analysis (Huang et al., 2020), and center of gravity migration (Xiao, 2018). Although the aforementioned studies have conducted in-depth analyses of the air quality in different regions and at different times in China, most of the studies have only analyzed the air qual- ity in local areas of China, ignoring the interaction of air pollutants in different regions and making it diffi- cult to measure the overall level of China‚Äôs air quality objectively and comprehensively. Thus, macrocon- trolling the policies and regulations of air pollution control is difficult from the overall perspective. The time scale is relatively short although a few scholars have studied the characteristics of air pollution at the national level, and grasping the overall characteristics of air quality in recent years is difficult. China‚Äôs air quality has improved in recent years. However, China is still in its infancy concerning air pollution control. According to the distri- bution of hot and cold spots, the air quality in North China and Xinjiang can be inferred as poor, while the air quality in southern China is relatively good. The reason for the hot spots in North China may be related to the fact that the region is mainly dominated by heavy industries such as coal and chemical indus- try, with a large amount of coal combustion and high pollutant emissions. Combined with the dense popu- lation distribution, living and traffic pollution emis- sions, and coal-fired heating in winter further aggra- vates air pollution. The Xinjiang region presents hot spots, mainly due to the dry climate, scarce precipi- tation, and frequent wind and sand activities, which leads to air pollution. At the same time, due to the scarcity of precipitation, there is less purification of pollutants. The sparse vegetation has a weak adsorp- tion effect on pollutants. The southern part of the country presents cold spots probably with the influ- ence of warm and humid air currents in the region, such as ocean currents and southeast monsoon, abundant precipitation, strong atmospheric mobility, strong purification and dilution of pollutants in the air, and better air quality. The air quality in the north- east is better than that in northern China, mainly due to the dense woodlands and wetlands, which have a stronger purification function for pollutants. And the population density in the northern region is relatively low, with less domestic pollutant emissions.

The ArcGIS spatial autocorrelation tool is used to con- duct a spatial statistical analysis of the annual AQI aver- age value in major cities in China from 2014 to 2020 to evaluate whether a spatial autocorrelation exists in the AQI of the whole study area. The analysis results show that the Moran I value is 0.640, which is greater than 0, indicating that the data shows a positive space corre- lation.
